necessary that I held my Eye at a good distance from them ffor 
by approaching nearer, although in the same inclinac[i]on of my 
eye, yet there <s>S<\s>emerged a blewish colour out of the white, wch 
by dilateing it Selfe more & more into the Black rendered the 
Circles less distinct and left the white a little tinged with redd 
& yellow. I found also, that by looking through a Slitt or oblong 
hole wch was narrower then the pupill of my Eye, & held close 
to it parallell to the Prisms, I could see the Circles much 
distincter & visible to a farr greater number then otherwise 
Obs:4. To observe more nicely the Order of the colours 
wch arose out of the white Circles as the rayes became lesse &
lesse inclined to the plate of Aire, I took two Object glasses 
the One a plane-convex for a fourteen foot Telescope, and the 
other a large double convex for one of fifty foot, and upon this 
laying the other with its plane side downewards I pressed 
them Slowly together to make the colours Successively emerge 
in the midle of the Circles, & then slowly lifted the upper 
Glasse from the lower to make them successively vanish again 
in the Same place, where being of a considerable breadth, I could 
more easily discerne them. And by this means I observed their 
Succession & Quantity to be as followeth.
Next to the pellucid Centrall Spott made by the Contact of 
the glasses, Succeeded Violet, Blew, White Yellow & Redd. The 
Violet and Blew were so very little in quantity that I could not 
discerne them in the circles made by ye Prisms; but the yellow &
red were pretty copious & seemed about as much in extent as the 
white, & 4 or 5 times more then the Blew & Violet. The next 
circuit or Order of Colours imediately incompassing these was 
Violet, Blew, Green, Yellow, & Red. And these were all of 
them copious & vivid, excepting the green, wch was very little in 
quantity, & seemed much more faint & dilute then the other colours 
Of the other foure the Violet was least & the blew lesse than the 
Yellow or Red. The third circuit or Order was also purple, Blew 
Green, Yellow & Red, in wch the Purple seemed more Reddish than ye 
Violet in the former circuit, & the green was much more 
conspicuous, being as brisk & copious as any of the other colours 
except the yellow, but the Redd began to be a little faded inclining 
very much to purple. After these Succeeded green & Red; The 
green was very copious & lively inclining on the one side to blew
